Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Modeling Post-Disaster Housing Recovery Integrating Performance Based Engineering and Urban Simulation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Following natural disasters in the United States, federal, state and local government officials must facilitate the recovery of the functionality and well-being of the affected communities. The housing sector plays a vital role in recovery because schools, businesses, neighborhoods and community-based organizations all rely on residents having healthy living conditions so that they can remain in the affected region. Existing disaster risk modeling methods are not able to adequately represent the housing recovery process and its long-term impacts to communities. This project will address this problem by developing and applying new data and computer model methods to simulate post-disaster housing recovery. The computer model will enable policy-makers and planners to quantify the benefits and tradeoffs associated with possible pre- and post-disaster housing interventions. They will be able to explore potential scenarios for various future hazard events towards the goal of enhancing housing recovery after disasters in the United States. To facilitate technology transfer to other researchers and disaster risk managers, the computer model and data from this project will be free, open source, and available over the World Wide Web. The research will provide training for a doctoral student and an opportunity to teach undergraduate students from different backgrounds about the role of science and engineering in improving the resilience of communities to natural disasters.

We will investigate key questions related to housing recovery using a post-disaster recovery simulation model that integrates building performance information and homeowner decision making over space and time. The three main components of the research are (1) a probabilistic model that computes building damage using data about loss of functionality, habitability, and repairability (2) a model that quantifies the influences and uncertainty associated with homeowners' decisions whether to repair, reoccupy, sell, or abandon damaged homes based on the extent of damage, demographics, neighborhood conditions, and utility services and (3) a simulation of post-disaster housing recovery, that accounts for the influences of building, homeowner, and resource attributes, such as housing stock and population movement. We will apply the simulation model to a large urban jurisdiction for the purposes of (a) evaluation, (b) hypothesis testing, (c) and assessing potential policies and other interventions for enhancing recovery. The project will further the science in performance-based engineering and urban modeling to facilitate experiments for examining the geographic effects of post-disaster residential building functionality and housing occupancy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Following natural disasters in the United States, federal, state and local government officials must facilitate the recovery of the functionality and well-being of the affected communities. The housing sector plays a vital role in this recovery because schools, businesses, neighborhoods and community-based organizations all rely on residents having healthy living conditions so that they can remain in the affected region. The primary goal of this project was to develop and apply new data and computer models to simulate disaster housing recovery.

We started by performing an exhaustive state-of-the-art review and synthesis of the literature toward building a consensus among researchers and practitioners on the most effective methods, datasets and tools for modeling disaster recovery. From this review, we determined that there is a need for future models to consider the dynamics of rental housing and the role of race and ethnicity. Additionally, there needs to be more of a coordinated research effort towards creating comprehensive multi-sector (e.g. housing, businesses, schools etc.) modeling platforms. Following the state-of-the-art review, we developed an integrated disaster recovery model that is able to (1) compute the geographic distribution of physical damage and functional loss to buildings caused by a natural hazard event while considering multiple sources of uncertainty (e.g. hazard intensity and building vulnerability) (2) probabilistically predict likely homeowner and renter decisions whether to repair, reoccupy, sell, or abandon damaged homes based on the extent of damage, demographics, neighborhood conditions, and utility services and (3) simulate housing recovery trajectories in terms of the physical state and occupancy of the affected residences while accounting for the influences of building, homeowner, and resource attributes (e.g. housing stock and population movement).

To develop the decision-making model, we conducted a survey of Los Angeles households, who were presented with hypothetical earthquake impact scenarios (e.g. damage to residence and neighborhood, loss of utilities and access to residence) and asked to choose between several relocation options under the conditions that they did or did not have earthquake insurance. A statistical analysis of the survey data revealed that the amount of time a household has spent in their current residence, the neighborhood evacuation level, physical damage to residence, duration of utility disruption and loss of access to the building, household income and earthquake insurance coverage had a strong association with homeowners’ decisions. However, only physical damage to the residence and duration of utility disruption were strongly associated renter decision-making. The integrated model was then tested using real recovery data from the  2014 South Napa Earthquake. We found that our model was able to adequately capture the overall trajectory as well as the effect of various building (e.g., age, occupancy, property value) and census-level sociodemographic factors (e.g., household income)  on recovery outcomes.

We also used the model to assess the effect of the recently enacted Los Angeles Soft-Story Ordinance on the post-earthquake housing recovery of residential communities. An inventory of approximately 8,000 buildings located in five Los Angeles neighborhoods was considered. The results from the case study showed that the quantified effect of the Los Angeles Ordinance retrofit varied based on the considered recovery metric. For instance, the initial loss of occupancy for the entire inventory is reduced by 25%. However, if the time to restore 90% occupancy is used as the recovery performance metric, the Ordinance retrofit leads to a 64% reduction.

The computer model that was developed as part of this research will enable policy-makers and planners to quantify the benefits and tradeoffs associated with possible pre- and post-disaster housing interventions. They will be able to explore potential scenarios for various future hazard events towards the goal of enhancing housing recovery after disasters in the United States. To facilitate technology transfer to other researchers and disaster risk managers, the computer model and data from this project has been published on GitHub, which is an open source software development platform. The project produced a woman PhD graduate. Nine undergraduate students worked on the project, five of whom are from groups that are under-represented in engineering and disaster research and practice (i.e. women, African Americans and Hispanics). To date, we have published four manuscripts in high-quality journals and six papers in conference proceedings. We expect at least two more journal papers to be published on this work.
